docs.snippet: Philip Seymour Hoffman is under very little pressure this year, having been nominated for best supporting actor for his role in "Charlie Wilson's War" - and it shows. Why such little pressure? Javier Bardem is the prohibitive favorite (He just won...
docs.lead_paragraph: Philip Seymour Hoffman is under very little pressure this year, having been nominated for best supporting actor for his role in "Charlie Wilson's War" -- and it shows. Why such little pressure? Javier Bardem is the prohibitive favorite (He just won, btw.) Hoffman is known as somebody with very little taste for the pomp and silliness of the awards campaign.
docs.abstract: Philip Seymour Hoffman is under very little pressure this year, having been nominated for best supporting actor for his role in "Charlie Wilson's War" - and it shows. Why such little pressure? Javier Bardem is the prohibitive favorite (He just won, btw.) Hoffman is known as somebody with very little taste for the pomp and [...]

docs.snippet: Ms. Cotillard, in a dress, one of the evening's most spectacular, that seemed to be made of translucent white fish scales, said, "In the main, its been fun. I told them I would do what they needed, do what was asked, and there has been very little...
docs.lead_paragraph: Marion Cotillard has been on the circuit for a month, going hither and yon in Los Angeles in support of "La Vie en Rose" and her nomination for best actress. Her English has improved rapidly -- "Why thank you!" --as has her understanding of the business. "I had no idea that a little French movie would go this far, but this is what you do once it does."
docs.abstract: Ms. Cotillard, in a dress, one of the evening's most spectacular, that seemed to be made of translucent white fish scales, said, "In the main, its been fun. I told them I would do what they needed, do what was asked, and there has been very little pressure."

docs.snippet: Will L.A. weather put a chill on the Oscars?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past few days, unseasonable cold and rain in Los Angeles has occasionally given way to some moments when the sun breaks through, bathing the city in welcome light and flicking at the dampness. People will scan the sky, turning their face toward sun that is generally a prerogative of living here. (Update: 11:30 PST. Sunny but chill.)
docs.abstract: Will L.A. weather put a chill on the Oscars?

headline.main: Kodak Moment: Intermittent Rain, a Stalled High Pressure System

docs.snippet: The show will go on, whether we like it or not. An Oscar preview....
docs.lead_paragraph: This year's Oscars would have seemed to be a great time to innovate, to put together a show on the fly that perhaps attacks some of the creakiness and convention that is part of Oscar gospel. Ain't. Gonna. Happen. In spite of the fact that organizers had little more than a week to put together the show, this will be no ad-hoc Oscars. Look for the same glorious goo to be poured into the extant template. People who have seen the auditions say that there is a palpable desire for normalcy, for business as usual, but that means the same brutal copy will show up on the teleprompter and be beamed straight at you.
docs.abstract: The show will go on, whether we like it or not. An Oscar preview.

docs.lead_paragraph: At yesterday's rehearsals, according to The Associated Press, Cameron Diaz, in a gray sweater, skinny black jeans and towering high heels, opened a prop winner's envelope and said, "The Oscar goes to - your mama. No, I'm just kidding."

docs.snippet: Could Clooney sneak through at the 80th annual Oscars....
docs.lead_paragraph: Yesteday, Tom O'Neil took a seat on the high wire, suggesting that George Clooney could sneak past Daniel Day-Lewis in the best actor category. He got some company yesterday. The Bagger bumped into Tom Bernard, the co-chief honcho at Sony Pictures Classics, at the Spirit Awards. Bernard has a pretty good record in Oscar matters and has good sources among old members of the Academy, although he was wearing sunglasses that play MP3's, so there is that. (Dog the Bounty Hunter, who is staying at the Bagger's hotel, has a similar pair.) And Bernard said that Day-Lewis may not be the lock we have all said he was. "You're probably right about Daniel Day-Lewis, but I wouldn't be surprised to see Clooney sneak in."
docs.abstract: Could Clooney sneak through at the 80th annual Oscars.

docs.snippet: The Bagger hits the low key Miramax pre-Oscar party....
docs.lead_paragraph: Last night's Miramax party had all the trappings of a major Oscar bacchanal. Tight door, movie stars, even an appearance by the elusive Cormac McCarthy (the author of "No Country for Old Men"). The Soho club here offered a great space and amazing views and even a smoking cage, a place where the muse often hunts the Bagger down, but no one wants to put both pom poms in the air - not the night before, and maybe not the night after. Strike, rain, macro-business problems, the death of Heath Ledger, blame it on whatever you want, but no one is doing the backstroke in Oscar froth this year.
docs.abstract: The Bagger hits the low key Miramax pre-Oscar party.

docs.snippet: For many Kazakhs, an Oscar nomination for “Mongol” is more than a milestone in the development of their film industry....
docs.lead_paragraph: For many Kazakhs, an Oscar nomination for “Mongol” is more than a milestone in the development of their film industry.
